title: Roald Dahl's Bond Script: A Glimpse into His Creative Process
summary: The original first draft manuscript of the James Bond film 'You Only Live Twice,' written by Roald Dahl in 1967, is currently on temporary display at the Roald Dahl Museum and Story Centre in Great Missenden, Buckinghamshire. This screenplay, based on Ian Fleming's book, was produced by Albert Broccoli and starred Sean Connery. Dahl, known for his children's literature, was a close friend of Fleming and was tasked with writing the script in just eight weeks. His background as a fighter pilot in World War II and his role in espionage, where he supplied intelligence to Winston Churchill, heavily influenced the film. For instance, a scene involving Bond flying an autogyro under fire mirrors Dahl's own dogfight experiences described in his autobiography. The display includes personal items like a photograph with the director, a 007 tie, and Dahl's boules set with a magnet invention, which also appears in the film. This exhibition illustrates how Dahl's inventive mind and real-life adventures enriched his writing, connecting his children's stories to his work on Bond.

background_read: Roald Dahl (1916-1990) was a British author famous for children's books such as 'Matilda' and 'The BFG,' but he also had a diverse career including serving as a fighter pilot in the Royal Air Force during World War II. After the war, he worked in intelligence in Washington, D.C., where he met Ian Fleming, the creator of James Bond. Fleming, who also had intelligence background, died in 1964, and Dahl was later approached by producer Cubby Broccoli to adapt Fleming's novel 'You Only Live Twice' into a screenplay. The Roald Dahl Museum, established in his hometown, preserves his legacy through archives of personal items, showcasing how his life influenced his writing. This context helps understand the blend of reality and fiction in his works.
